Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 05:55PM echosalvaje wrote: MarieKelly is right, hydrogen peroxide will bubble on ANYTHING. I had bi-lat mast so there was no breast hanging around getting in the way but the whole area that was radiated did start bubbling off into a seeping mess. And yes, it was terribly painful. Do you have any vicoden or percoset hanging around from surgery? My rads onc told me to use that for pain. Laying in a position so that air can get to it really does help. I would walk around the house all day without a shirt with my arm up in the air, ( would have been considered BIDDING at an auction house ).  I would also spend a fair amount of time in the shower letting warm water run over the tissue to flush out the dead skin. Debriding (dead skin removal) is how burn victims are treated. That's why it's such a long and painful process. The silvadene did work for me when I put it on after the shower and patting dry. Airing out before the silvadene is key. I can tell you that after about two weeks from the end of my rads, you could hardly tell that the area had been such a mess. I am sorry you are having to go thru this misery.  It just doesn't seem fair, eh? But, after all we've been through you will come out the other side wiser and stronger than you ever thought. Hang in there girl.
Posts.Title: Rads burn peeling and seeping yellow/greenish snot looking stuff buccaneersdj Bethie1

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2010 09:19PM echosalvaje wrote: Ah the hair delimma. I wasn't too freaked out about losing my hair from chemo because I had to shave my head and whole body for two months when I was in the play "WIT" a couple of years ago. Once it was over everything just grew in like normal..............growing in from chemo has not been normal.........I am 6 months out from Cytoxan/Taxoterre and the hair on my head is about 11/2 inches long and quite a bit curlier than before, it has been white for years and still is. I wanted to post a picture in this text but can't get it to work..does anyone know the trick? The disturbing thing is that my eyebrows and lashes have all fallen out again in the past week or so. When they grew in, they were really short, so short that putting mascara on was a major mess so I didn't bother. Now they're gone again.
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2010 09:32AM echosalvaje wrote: It has been many months since I was last on this website. Having finished treatment at the end of 2009 and starting to get my body back over this year, I found that I had to break away from these pages so that I could "get my life back." Ironically, the horse thread was the first thing to pop up when I logged in, and boy do I need it! I wasn't strong enough to ride during my whole treatment episode so unfortunately Echo, my 11 year old BLM wild horse that I raised after he was gathered as a weanling, stood around for over a year. One day in June I finally felt ready to "get back on that horse" and was feeling really inspired and did something totally stupid. I just hopped up on him bareback in my pasture. I of course had no balance or leg strength, he was surprised and I think a little mortified that I would assume the "inspiration" was mutual, so he promptly bucked me off into a pile of rocks and I fractured three ribs, tore cartilage and bruised my lung. Stupid, stupid, stupid!!! My initial response was to quit horses, sell everything and find a new sport, afterall, I hadn't just spent the past year in the hardest battle of my life only to get killed by my horse, right? For the past 3 months he's been up at a friends boarding barn being ridden by several people so that I could have him in shape to sell. Every time I'd go up to check on him they'd tell me how much fun he is to ride and what a great mover he is yadda yadda yadda. I was still feeling the hurt of broken ribs and pretty much held my ground about my decision to sell him. The only thing holding me up  was that several of my friends and I were supposed to ride our horses in the 100 Year Celebration of the Pendleton RoundUp. This parade is one of the last in the country that is non-motorized and usually has about 500-600 horses in it each year. Well, the idea that I'd miss out on the Centennial really started to fester in my mind.  Five days before the parade I got up the nerve to get on my boy. I was really afraid. I just didn't want to get hurt again. I was still very weak. He took such good care of me and the feeling that you get only on the back of a horse seeped into every cell of my body. Three days later we were on our way to Pendleton to spend the week at the rodeo. We did the parade. I sobbed tears of joy practically the whole way. This parade broke the Guinness Book of World Records for the largest number of horses in a parade at over 1600! It was so fun! So, we came home. I'm not selling him, but I am going to keep boarding him so that others can keep riding him until I get my old strength back. I am totally out of breath after about two times around the arena at a trot. It's nice to have a partner to work out with. I keep having that saying in the back of my mind about "the best thing for the inside of a woman/man, is the outside of a horse." So true...........
Posts.Title: Horseback riding chele Claire_in_Seattle

Posts.Content: Oct 6, 2010 11:19AM echosalvaje wrote: @squid, I have three acres with a barn at my house. I currently have two very adorable donkeys and my gelding. I had to put my dreamhorse Kelly, a Morgan mare, down the year before my cancer came along. She's buried out in field with a lovely red maple planted over her. (She's who I'm riding in my avatar photo). I usually have everyone home but decided to board my horse up the road at a boarding barn for the winter because they have a covered arena and it will cause me to get out more in the bad weather to ride. Typically I trail ride, go camping alot in the summer with my horse. We used to be able to go right from the house years ago to trails nearby but over the past 10 years our small town has become a tourist mecca for all things sports related, so the trails are packed with mountain bikers, motorcycles, etc. I usually trailer to whatever neck of the woods within a 30 minute to 1 hour drive that has the best weather that day. Riding in an arena bores the hell out of me and my guy, so I do a lesson every week to keep us motivated and less lazy.
Posts.Title: Horseback riding chele Claire_in_Seattle

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2010 10:02PM echosalvaje wrote: Hey Deb, did you ever think your "Rant" would garner so much debate? Whew....getting through all these stepped on feelings on a day dedicated to love is proving to be a bit overwhelming! One of my motto's in life has been, "you don't have to ask for my opinion....I give it freely." That said, I am sure that I have posted the "wrong" words in the "wrong" place too. Sorry. I love that the learning never stops....never tooo old for that! The thing that really breaks my heart when I see these debates getting into that "pissing match" morass is that the bottom line here is that, your "hell", is "your" hell. Some days, my hell is a paper cut. Some days it is thinking about my son trying to commit suicide or that my daughter may have to fight this BC monster. Your hell is your hell and nobody has any business judging how "hellish" that is. I come here for support and knowledge. I will continue to come here for support and knowledge and after everyone on these boards manages to get through this "rant", I imagine all the information will be given with a new sense of kindness and respect. Sending love to all of you beautiful ladies.
Posts.Title: RESPECTING the STAGE threads **RANT** cherneski Nico1012

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2010 11:32PM echosalvaje wrote: For those of you thinking about getting back into horses but not sure of how your body will react to brushing, tacking up, getting pushed or pulled around by your horse etc. consider this. I have a friend that I've ridden with for years. Both of her Morgan geldings have retired due to lameness issues. She and her husband leave the Pacific Northwest for 6 months each winter. For the past two summers she has leased horses. Both times she wound up with great matches. The first one was a big overweight Hafflinger that was huge, a gentle giant. He was like riding a sofa. This summer she had just the opposite, a really small Icelandic pony, sweet as can be and lots of fun to ride. The best part is when summer is over, she hands them back to their owners and has no committment. Right now with the economy being the way it is, lots of people have horses standing around that could use some love and attention. Putting an ad in your local classifieds or dropping the word at barns in your area letting people know you have interest is a great way to try out several different horses knowing that if it doesn't work out you can return them to their owner and try another.
Posts.Title: Horseback riding chele Claire_in_Seattle

Posts.Content: Oct 5, 2010 11:34PM echosalvaje wrote: Helpful horses, I wish I could get mine to paint the house! Here's a funny story that happened a couple of summers ago. I generally keep quite a few toys out in the yard for my guys, two donkeys and my mustang. They like to mess around with hula-hoops, old tires, dog toys and feed tubs, whatever is around. It had been really hot that year and we kept rotating the boys around to the other pastures so we could water the empty ones. My gelding loves to play with the sprinklers. He'll stand right in front of it while it rotates around in a circle and he scoots along with it so that his chest and belly get wet, then he goes over to the dustbowl and rolls...comes back, gets wet, goes and rolls...this can go on for hours. Our irrigation system is run from a pump in one of the pastures next to our barn. I had started the water that morning which always entails priming the pump, moving the hoses, changing pipes all around. About ten minutes after I went back in the house, I noticed the water stopped and I thought a filter needed cleaning so I go out clean the filters, prime the pump essentially do everything all over again, get the water going and go inside to make coffee. Now you see, every time I have to go out to screw around with the irrigation, the boys have to stand there and help me out which then leads to scratching and petting etc. I get my coffee made and sit down with a good book and notice that it's awfully quiet outside....the water is off again....DANG! I storm out the door and head for the pump once again and notice my mustang is standing nearby, sort of waiting for me to get the water started again, hhhmmmmmmm. So, I start the pump again, go inside, peek out the window and see him standing next to the pump, looking at the front door of the house. A few minutes later, he bends his head down and uses his teeth to swing the valve off enough that it causes the pump to turn off, and stands there looking at the door waiting for me to come back out! TALK ABOUT PAVLOVS DOG! My horse had me totally trained. He knew everytime I had to come back out to get the water going it meant another scratch on the belly and "oh, isn't this game fun Mom?" Even the donkeys were impressed. Ultimately my husband had to build a box around it and of course the boys were right in there, handing him the tools and telling him how it should be done !!

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2009 12:02AM echosalvaje wrote: Hey there "threebies", I was diagnosed this year at 51. Had bilat, my last Cytoxan/Taxotere is next week and I've got seven weeks of rads coming up. While I am super glad that these discussion boards are here to support us, there is a part of me that will be happy when BC doesn't creep into every conversation. When I asked my ONC about how to test to see if all these treatments are working, he said we just wait to see if it comes back, there's no test, he says, hmmmm........I have been having one of those weeks where it's hard to see the end of treatment because I'm still so sick from chemo, so I go to the boards where they talk about being done and getting their life back to something more normal and that gives me the reminder that THIS is going to be done soon. Thanks for being out there ladies!

Posts.Content: echosalvaje wrote: I have only had two rounds of Cytoxan/Taxotere but I am seeing a pattern in a disturbing side effect. My cycle begins on Wed. on Thurs. I get a shot of Neulasta, and by Fri. morning I am having rapid irregular heartbeat. The first time I thought, "oh, so this is what chemo feels like." I had tremors all day with my heart flipping and flopping all over the place. By that afternoon I was in the emergency room hooked up to the monitors declaring I had A-fib. By 7:00pm I converted back to normal on my own.  Well, it happened again this go 'round. Except this time it lasted longer. I chose not to go to the ER because I knew there was nothing they could really do except watch me. I finally converted on my own 36 hours later. Other than bone pain from the Neulasta shot, my side effects are minimal. I get Emend, Zofran and Compazine for nausea and vomiting and I am happy to report that they work for me and I have avoided that misery. I wonder if it's all the drugs combined causing the A-fib, or something specific. At this point my Onc has not been able to define any solution. Has anyone else had to deal with this? It is true some days are difficult, but can you recall any day in the past that you failed to survive? Bilateral mastectomy, no reconstruction. Chemo, rads, tamox. Dx 3/6/2009, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 2, 7/18 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply
